Plus largement, de nombreux exemplesÂ dÃ©montrent les effets attendusÂ [1]Â dâ€™une plus grande ouverture des donnÃ©es publiques:

  • une progression trÃ¨s nette de la rÃ©utilisation des donnÃ©es, tant en nombre et diversitÃ© de rÃ©utilisateurs que de frÃ©quence dâ€™usage. En France, le passage Ã  la gratuitÃ© du RÃ©fÃ©rentiel Ã  grande Ã©chelle de lâ€™IGN pour les acteurs chargÃ©s dâ€™une mission de service public sâ€™est traduit par une multiplication par 20 de lâ€™usage des donnÃ©es,
  • un rapport coÃ»ts / bÃ©nÃ©fices trÃ¨s favorable, tant pour le secteur public que privÃ© – de 1 Ã  13 pour les donnÃ©es gÃ©o spatiales australiennes, parmi les premiÃ¨res Ã  Ãªtre ouvertes dÃ¨s 2006,
  • une dynamisation du marchÃ© aval des services fondÃ©s sur les donnÃ©es, avec lâ€™apparition de nouveaux acteurs et une incitation plus forte Ã  innover pour les acteurs historiques. Aux Etats-Unis, la dÃ©cision du National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOOA) dâ€™ouvrir leurs donnÃ©es a permis la crÃ©ation dâ€™une industrie mÃ©tÃ©orologique qui pÃ¨se aujourdâ€™hui plusieurs milliards de dollars dans lâ€™Ã©conomie amÃ©ricaineÂ [2],
  • une rÃ©duction des coÃ»ts de transaction et de lâ€™asymÃ©trie dâ€™information dont les bÃ©nÃ©fices concernent tout autant les acteurs publics que privÃ©s. Le Danemark a ainsi calculÃ© que 70% des bÃ©nÃ©fices de lâ€™ouverture des donnÃ©es dâ€™adresses revenaient au secteur privÃ© et 30% au secteur public, pour un retour sur investissement de 14 millions â‚¬ de bÃ©nÃ©fices contre un coÃ»t de 0,2 million â‚¬ en 2010Â [3],
  • une lutte accrue contre la corruption et la fraude fiscale par la rÃ©duction des asymÃ©tries dâ€™information. Au Canada en 2010, une fraude fiscale de 3,1 milliards de dollars a pu Ãªtre identifiÃ©e grÃ¢ce aux donnÃ©es ouvertesÂ [4]. En Ukraine, une fraude dâ€™un 1.8 milliards de dollars a Ã©galement Ã©tÃ© dÃ©tectÃ©eÂ [5].

[1] Voir Â«Â Open Data for Economic GrowthÂ Â» (World Bank, 2014) et Â«Â The Generative Mechanisms of Open Government DataÂ Â» (Jetzek Thorhildur, 2013), Â«Â Cost and benefits of data provisionÂ Â» (Victoria University, 2011).

[2] http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/07/business/media/07weather.html?_r=0

[3] http://www.adresse-info.dk/Portals/2/Benefit/Value_Assessment_Danish_Address_Data_UK_2010-07-07b.pdf

[4] http://eaves.ca/2010/04/14/case-study-open-data-and-the-public-purse/

[5] http://rue89.nouvelobs.com/2015/11/02/demandez-a-quoi-sert-lopen-data-allez-voir-ukraine-261916

[:en]

On January 12, 2016 Axelle Lemaire organized the #DataDay, a conference-debate on openness strategies in data economics, with big corporations and startups alike. Among them were Data Publica and SNIPS, two previous winners of the Dataconnexions contest. The Minister of State for Digital Affairs seized the opportunity to announce the free opening, in open data of the SIRENE repository managed by the national statistics institute INSEE, on January 1, 2017. The many possibilities of reuses and cross analysis offered by opening up this repository will create new economic opportunities.

.

Â« Sirene RepositoryÂ Â» The biggest database on company civil status

The SIRENE company register gathers economical and legal information on close to 10 million businesses and branches across all sectors of activity in metropolitan France and overseas departments. On average, 10,000 updates are submitted every day. The INSEE works with a lot of actors, like commercial courts clerks, gathering information on matriculations, radiations and changes made to the repository. This makes SIRENE among the worldâ€™s most complete databases, it contains essential economical information and identification, including:

  • The address of facilities and their legal status;
  • The SIRET/SIREN ID Number: The SIREN number is a unique ID number assigned to each business by the INSEE. This number identifies a legal person from its creation until its termination. The SIRET number is assigned to each branch. It comprises the SIREN number and an internal ranking number (NIC). With those two codes, all the facilities in France are identified;
  • The APE code: Every operating business has a code characterizing its major activity in reference to the classification of economic activities. This code allows precise statistics on activity sectors in France;
  • The database for the size of the workforce by segment for businesses and facilitiesâ€¦

SIREN ought to be amongst the Â«Â donnÃ©es de referenceÂ Â» (key databases used as a reference) defined in the Digital Republic Bill, currently discussed in the French parliament, as it is likely to be widely and frequently used by a great number of actors and its quality is essential for reuses.

A major economic impact

By opening this register, France honors its commitments in the G8 Open Data Charter and could join the leading countries that already opened their company registers like Norway, the UK, Australia, Indonesia or Romania.

All actors, public (administrations, territorial authoritiesâ€¦) and private (companies, non-profitsâ€¦) will access the data free of charge. Opening the repository will enrich the list of databases already published in open data by the INSEE, one of data.gouv.frâ€™s largest data provider. It will complement company data released by the DILA (Boamp, Bodacc and Balo), the INPI (brands, patents, and drawings), Infogreffe and the National Register of Commerce and Companies (RNCS).

The awaited economic impact is massive, given the positive externalities associated with this opening: availability of key data, increasing reliability of studies and market researches, efficiency of public policies etc. Furthermore, a lot of examples demonstrate the awaited effects [1]of Open Data:

  • a clear increase in reuses in terms of volume, diversity and frequency. In France, the switch to gratuity of public service repertories for government entities from the national geographic institute (IGN) saw 20 times more reuses,
  • a very advantageous cost/benefit ratio both for the public and private sector – 1 to 13 for Australian geospatial data-,
  • a revitalization of the data-based service industry, with new actors and a bigger innovation incentive for historic actors. In the US, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrationâ€™s decision to open its data allowed the creation a multibillion meteorological industry.[2],
  • a transaction cost reduction and information asymmetry reduction whose benefits could concern private and public actors. Denmark calculated that 70% of the benefits of open data would benefit private sector and 30% public sector, with a return on investment of â‚¬14 million in benefits for only â‚¬0,2 million in costs, in 2010[3],
  • a strengthened effort against corruption and tax evasion thanks to information asymmetry reduction. In Canada in 2010, a tax evasion of $3,1 billion was identified thanks to open data. [4]. In Ukraine, a $1,8 billion fraud was detectedÂ [5].

[1] See Â«Â Open Data for Economic GrowthÂ Â» (World Bank, 2014) et Â«Â The Generative Mechanisms of Open Government DataÂ Â» (Jetzek Thorhildur, 2013), Â«Â Cost and benefits of data provisionÂ Â» (Victoria University, 2011).

[2] http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/07/business/media/07weather.html?_r=0

[3] http://www.adresse-info.dk/Portals/2/Benefit/Value_Assessment_Danish_Address_Data_UK_2010-07-07b.pdf

[4] http://eaves.ca/2010/04/14/case-study-open-data-and-the-public-purse/

[5] http://rue89.nouvelobs.com/2015/11/02/demandez-a-quoi-sert-lopen-data-allez-voir-ukraine-261916[:]

item.content:encoded:
On June 18th, 2013 at the Lough Erne Summit, the President of the French Republic and the chiefs of State and Government of the G8 Member States adopted anÂ Open Data CharterÂ which marked our collective commitment toÂ â€œopen economies, open societies and open governments as the basis of lasting growth and stabilityâ€.

The French Prime Minister just released anÂ Action Plan for FranceÂ to implement the commitments laid out in theÂ G8 Open Data Charter and its technical annex.

G8 Summit in Lough Erne, 18 June 2013 â€” Photo credits: French Presidency of the Republic

The Governmentâ€™s commitment to transparency and Open Data stems from a long republican and democratic tradition in France. Article 15 of theÂ Declaration of the Rights of Man and the CitizenÂ of 26 August 1789 states that â€œSociety has the right to require of every public agent an account of its administration.â€

The development of Open Data policy in France, starting in 2011 with the creation of theÂ Prime Ministerâ€™s taskforce EtalabÂ (data.gouv.fr) for Open Governement Data, marked a resolute commitment to foster innovation, economic growth and government reform in addition to this long-standing commitment to transparency.

ThisÂ Action Plan for FranceÂ summarizes the context of Open Government Policy in our country and presents the main priorities for further development to which the French government is committing:

  • Progressing towardsÂ publishing data openly by default
  • Building anÂ open platformÂ to encourage innovation and transparency
  • Developing Open Data policy inÂ consultation with citizensand civil society
  • Supporting open innovationÂ in France and throughout the world

The action plan is released here:

  • English: Action Plan for France – G8 Open Data Charter
  • French: Plan dâ€™Action pour la France – Charte Open Data du G8

The French Prime Minister just released anÂ Action Plan for FranceÂ to implement the commitments laid out in theÂ G8 Open Data Charter and its technical annex.
